export.access: Original may be examined and handled by Archives patrons. Use of cotton gloves required. No pens, pencils or other writing instruments permitted in the exam area without permission of curator. Original item is in very fragile condition and must be handled carefully. Photocopies are available.
export.admin: Ernestine McMillan Hilton was an educator and activist for children's rights from 1940 to 1975. She was active in the local, state, and national PTA. She served as the president of the Washington State PTA in the late 1960's. During the period from 1946 to 1999 Ernestine and Earl L. Hilton owned and operated the Rocky Pine Ranch, a dairy operation near Cheney, WA.
export.associate: Catalog # 85.1.2 - Cheney Museum of History - Unpublished Manuscript by Ernestine McMillan Hilton entitled, Fundraising for Education. 1958.
export.caption: Autograph Album Cover
export.condnotes: 05/18/2001- Examined. Damage to item noted. See Detailed Damage Report. PAT
export.copies: Photocopies are available for examination at PastPerfect Museum.
export.credit: In memory of the pioneers of Spokane County
export.custodial: The autograph album was in the possession of Ernestine McMillan Hilton from 1930 to 1999. In 1999 the album was transferred to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.descrip: Folded leather cover with 32 leaves. This autograph album contains poems and greetings written to Ernestine McMillan by her classmates between 1930 and 1933 while in elementary school. She would have been between 10 and 12 years of age when this autograph album was in use. The pages of the book are blue, pink, and white and are written on both sides.
export.extent: 1 book - Folded leather cover with 32 leaves
export.findaid: See: Guide to Historical Document Holdings at the PastPerfect Museum. 1999.
export.legal: Transferred by Deed of Gift to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.originals: Original located in PastPerfect Museum Repository.
export.physchar: Folded leather cover with 32 leaves. The word "Autographe" is printed in gold script across the front cover.- The pages of the book are blue, pink, and white and have hand-written messages on both sides. The book measures 16 cm x 12 cm. The cover is one piece of leather which is folded. There are two perforations that match perforations in the leaves. The book is held together with a brown cord threaded through the holes and tied.
export.related: 1999.001.0001 - Photograph of Ernestine McMillan Hilton 1999.001.0002 - Photograph of Ernestine McMillan Hilton
export.rights: All copyrights have been transferred from the original owner to the PastPerfect Museum without restriction.
export.system: Archives Cabinet 5 contains diaries, letters, correspondence, and other items that are not parts of a larger fonds or collection. These items are contained in individual file folders and filed by object name / last name and are in alphabetical order.
export.title: Autograph Album of Ernestine McMillan Hilton

export.access: May be used under supervision in the research room. Cotton gloves required.
export.credit: In memory of the pioneers of Spokane County
export.descrip: Official Automobile Road Map of the State of Oregon was published in 1923 and shows all through trunk highways and main traveled roads, with mileages. The map's key shows that paved roads are in red and rock or gravel surfaced roads are in yellow. The year 1923 appears in the center of the map in red outlined letters 1 1/4" in height.
export.extent: 1 page map printed on one side only
export.insets: In the LL quadrant of the map an inset entitled "FOR THE MOTORIST" lays out the rules of the road.
export.legal: This map belongs to the PastPerfect Museum by deed of gift.
export.rights: Copyrights remain with the Oregon State Highway Commission
export.system: Maps are arrange in the flat file in the following manner: Drawer 1 contains topo maps & world maps. Drawer 2 contains small scale road maps. Drawer 3 contains city maps and plans. Drawer 4 contains early historic maps and facsimiles. Within the drawers the maps are arranged by object ID number with larger numbers on the top going to smaller numbers at the bottom.
export.title: State Highway department's Official Automobile Road Map of the State of Oregon Showing All Through Trunk Highways and Main Traveled Roads, With Mileages

export.access: Archives visitors may examine the original postcard but it must remain in the mylar sleeve. Cotton gloves are required.
export.caption: I'm training for this.
export.credit: In memory of my mother, Rosemary Hollis Kittridge
export.custodial: This item was received by Mr. Warner Laurence in June of 1918. It was later acquired by Rosemary Hollis Kittridge who gave it to the PastPerfect Museum by bequest in 2000.
export.descrip: This is a WWI era postcard. This postcard was manufactured by the Illustrated Postal Card & Novelty Co. of New York. It depicts an American doughboy apprehending a goose-stepping Kaiser Wilhelm with the inscription, "I'm training for this". The verso of the card bears this handwritten message; "Hoot Mon Well Warner how are you. Am feeling fine drilling hard every day hope you are feeling the Bluest. Charlie" It is addressed to Mr. Warner Laurence 74 Third St. Gloversville, N.Y. The card was post marked in Spartanburg, SC at 5 PM on June 5, 1918.
export.legal: All rights are presumed to be with PastPerfect Museum. The Illustrated Postal Card and Novelty Co. is no longer in business.
export.physchar: This postcard is made of two pieces of paper laminated together. The lamination is separating from he right upper corner. There is a tear in the middle top area of the card that corresponds to three thumbtack holes. See close-up photo.
export.related: See other WWI era postcards in the Postcard Collection
export.rights: Reproduction must be approved in writing by the Executive Director of the PastPerfect Museum.
export.system: This postcard is in the Postcard File / Box 3. Postcards are arranged by subject and by Object ID number. This card is in the World War I subject category.
export.title: I'm training for this

export.appnotes: Christmas postcard. Illustration of fireplace mantle hung with two large stockings and one small stocking. Mantle is embellished with a candle and garland of holly. Verso of card has hand-written message addressed to Mrs. Schmutz of Ann Arbor, MI. The stamp has been removed but the postmark is clearly readable as "Detroit, MI. Dec. 23, 1915". Value is mainly based on condition and rarity. Christmas postcards are relatively abundant, however this one is in considered rare.

export.credit: In memory of my mother, Rosemary Hollis Kittridge

Greeting reads, "To You--Merry Christmas May your stocking be filled with many a toy, And the song in your heart be, "Joy, Joy, Joy"". Verso of card has hand-written message addressed to Mrs. Schmutz of Ann Arbor, MI. The stamp has been removed but it was cancelled in Detroit, MI. Dec. 23, 1915.

export.access: Researchers may listen to the tape or use the transcript in the museum study room.
export.admin: Ernestine Hilton was an educator and activist for children's rights from 1940 to 1970. She was active in the local, state, and national PTA. She served as the president of the Washington State PTA in the late 1960's. During the period from 1946 to 1999 Ernestine and Earl Hilton ran the Rocky Pine Ranch, a dairy operation near Cheney, Wa.
export.caption: Hilton, Ernestine McMillan
export.classes: Agriculture Domestic Life World War II
export.copies: Transcript located in Oral History file cabinet, alphabetically arranged by subjects' last names.
export.creator: Paulette Nordquist
export.descrip:
1 hour audio tape containing the voices of Ernestine McMillan Hilton and interviewer, Paulette Nordquist.
Topics 1. Memories of growing up on a wheat ranch in Eastern Washington during the 1920's. 2. Recollections of having polio as a very young child. 3. Courtship and marriage during World War Two. 5. Life on a dairy ranch 1950-1970. 6. Description of Christmas and other holiday traditions at the ranch.
export.extent: 1 - 60 minute audio tape of oral history interview
export.intvrest: All copyrights belong to the PastPerfect Museum. Any reproduction or use of this material must be approved by the Curator of Collections.
export.legal: Oral History Project tapes belong to the PastPerfect Museum.
export.originals: Original tape resides in the archives at the PastPerfect Museum.
export.people: Hilton, Ernestine McMillan Hilton, Lura Cox
export.related: See related objects field under Condition Tab.
export.rights: All rights belong to the PastPerfect Museum. See signed waiver of rights in accession file.
export.subjects: Ranches Diseases World War II Poliomyelitis
export.system: All oral history tapes are contained in storage boxes in the archives. They are organized by year and by object id number within the boxes.
export.title: Oral History Tape of Ernestine McMillan Hilton

export.caption: page 1
export.creator: Hanley, Harold W.
export.credit: For my father, Clair Norton Hanley
export.descrip: Letter from Major Harold W. Hanley to his son, Warren Hanley, regarding life in the remote mining town of Camp Bird in the mountains of Colorado. The author recounts two incidents. The first is of a young man, Wilfred Noel, attempting to ski and snowshoe to town to cash his paycheck and getting lost along the way. The second incident is about a man who became ill with a high fever and had to be treated using "heroic measures".
export.extent: 1 letter comprised of 5 pages of 8" x 10" parchment paper.
export.notes: Camp Bird is named after just that, "Camp Birds", a common bird that ate many a miners lunch. When this mine was discovered by Andy Richardson, hired by Thomas Walsh, his lunch had just been eaten by the birds; hence the name Camp Bird. The Camp Bird mine site soon covered 900 acres. It eventually was the second largest gold mine in the state of Colorado. Walsh sold the property for 5.2 million in 1902. Walsh eventually purchased the "Hope" diamond and later died in 1909. The mine produced between 30 and 50 million and is still producing today. Upper Camp Bird was where some of the other mines were located and a tramway system carried men and ore up and down.
export.title: Letter from Major Harold W. Hanley to Warren Hanley

export.authorx: Warren T. Hanley Clair Norton Hanley
export.credit: For my father, Clair Norton Hanley
export.descrip: The earliest of these family papers include a letter from Grandpa Hanley to his son Warren T Hanley. The bulk of the material deal with the World War II memorabilia of Warren's son, Clair Norton Hanley, who was an ensign in the navy and served in the Pacific Fleet. His small vessel was involved in several defining operations, including the invasion of Japan and the Philipines. The fonds includes the following: 3 - Letters 3 - Certificates 10 - B&W photographs - Naval subjects WWII 1 - Uniform bar with 3 stars 1 - Diary 1945
export.extent: 3 - Letters 3- Certificates 10 - B&W photographs - Naval subjects WWII 1 - Uniform bar with 3 stars 1 - Diary 1945
export.notes: Camp Bird is named after just that, "Camp Birds", a common bird that ate many a miners lunch. When this mine was discovered by Andy Richardson, hired by Thomas Walsh, his lunch had just been eaten by the birds; hence the name Camp Bird. The Camp Bird mine site soon covered 900 acres. It eventually was the second largest gold mine in the state of Colorado. Walsh sold the property for 5.2 million in 1902. Walsh eventually purchased the "Hope" diamond and later died in 1909. The mine produced between 30 and 50 million and is still producing today. Upper Camp Bird was where some of the other mines were located and a tramway system carried men and ore up and down.
export.title: Hanley Family Collection

export.admin: The Office of Price Administration or OPA was a U.S. federal agency in World War II, established to prevent wartime inflation. The OPA issued (April, 1942) a general maximum-price regulation that made prices charged in March, 1942, the ceiling prices for most commodities. Ceilings were also imposed on residential rents. These regulations were gradually modified and extended by OPA administratorsnotably Leon Henderson (1941-42), Prentiss H. Brown (1943), and Chester B. Bowles (1943-46)until almost 90% of the retail food prices were frozen. Prices continued to rise, however, and new drives to secure compliance resulted; ultimately the OPA succeeded in keeping consumer prices relatively stable during the remaining war years. Besides controlling prices, the OPA was also empowered to ration scarce consumer goods in wartime. Tires, automobiles, sugar, gasoline, fuel oil, coffee, meats, and processed foods were ultimately rationed. At the end of the war rationing was abandoned, and price controls were gradually abolished. The agency was finally disbanded in 1947.
export.appnotes: U.S. Government War Ration Book Four. This book was issued to Charlotte E. Spencer of Torrington, Wyoming. This item is extremely fragile and friable. Although the book contains many of its original stamps they have become detached. The poor condition of the book has a negative effects on value. However, due to the relative rarity of the item (most books were either used up or returned to the OPA) it is worth between $30.00 and $60.00 at the time of this appraisal.
export.appraisal: This item to be held in perpetuity at the PastPerfect Museum.
export.archnotes: Description prepared by S. Odum, September 2001.
export.associate: More examples of War Ration Books are available at the World War Two Museum of Pottstown, 1234 S. Union Street, Pottstown, PA. 19342. 610-555-5678.
export.authorx: United States Office of Price Administration
export.copies: Photocopy in the collection of the World War Two Museum of Pottstown, 1234 S. Union Street, Pottstown, PA. 19342. 610-555-5678.
export.creator: U.S. Government Printing Office
export.custodial: 1943 - Issued to Charlotte E. Spencer 1945-1967 - Owned by Charlotte E. Spencer 1968-1986 - Owned by Evelyn P. Argyle (Daughter of Charlotte Spencer) 1986-2003 - Owned by Harrison Spencer (brother of Charlotte Spencer) 2004 - Donated to the PastPerfect Museum
export.descdate: Description prepared September 2001. Description revised January 2004.
export.descrip: U.S. Government War Ration Book Four. This book was issued to Charlotte E. Spencer of Torrington, Wyoming. Charlotte Spencer was four years old in 1943. The book was signed for by her mother, Esther E. Spencer. Books such as this were the mechanism by which commodities were rationed during World War II. Resources such as gas, coffee, and sugar were regulated. This book was issued in 1943 and still contains many of the original stamps.
export.extent: Folded brown paper cover printed on both sides to form a booklet. Inside contains stamps with perforations to facilitate removal. Several loose stamps are attached to the front cover with straight pins. There is a white string sewn along the spine of the covers.
export.findaid: See: Guide to the Archival Collections of the PastPerfect Museum. 2004.
export.legal: May be photographed by permission of the Curator of Collections, PastPerfect Archives.
export.notes: This item belonged to the donor's sister Charlotte who was 4 years old at the time it was issued. It was signed for by the child's mother Esther E. Spencer.
export.originals: Original resides in the PastPerfect Museum Archives. See Location Information.
export.physchar: This item is extremely fragile and friable. Handling shall be minimized by using digital images and photocopies. Anyone handling the item must wear cotton gloves.
export.related: See Accession #2003.1 for WWII related materials.
export.rights: May be photographed by permission of the Curator of Collections, PastPerfect Archives.

export.descrip:
3 Letters
1916 Letter from Major Harold W. Hanley to his son, Warren Hanley, regarding life in the remote mining town of Camp Bird in the mountains of Colorado. The author recounts two incidents. The first is of a young man, Wilfred Noel, attempting to ski and snowshoe to town to cash his paycheck and getting lost along the way. The second incident is about a man who became ill with a high fever and had to be treated using "heroic measures".
1938 A one-page letter, typewritten, from Herbert Hoover to Warren T. Hanley. It is dated 12/28/1938. The letter is a response to a letter sent by Mr. Hanley on 12/24/1938. Hoover discusses the fact that people are tired of politics after an election.
1944 A one-page letter, from Warren T. Hanley to his son, Clair, on the occasion of his marriage to Helen Torgeson. The father offers marriage advice to his son.
export.notes: Camp Bird is named after just that, "Camp Birds", a common bird that ate many a miners lunch. When this mine was discovered by Andy Richardson, hired by Thomas Walsh, his lunch had just been eaten by the birds; hence the name Camp Bird. The Camp Bird mine site soon covered 900 acres. It eventually was the second largest gold mine in the state of Colorado. Walsh sold the property for 5.2 million in 1902. Walsh eventually purchased the "Hope" diamond and later died in 1909. The mine produced between 30 and 50 million and is still producing today. Upper Camp Bird was where some of the other mines were located and a tramway system carried men and ore up and down.

Hanley for his naval service during World War II and gives his separation date as February 25, 1946. 02/25/1946 U.S. Government World War II Archives Room 201 MS Box 12 Folder 8 Notice of Separation from U.S. Naval Service 8" x 10.5" form that details Lt. (jg) Clair N. Hanley's naval service, lists his medals and awards, and lists the ships upon which he served. 02/25/1946 U.S. Government World War II
export.credit: For my father, Clair Norton Hanley

export.access: This film is in the public domain.
export.admin:
This film was made on December 8, 1941. It shows Franklin D. Roosevelt, President of the United States, making a speech to Congress following the attack by the Japanese on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii.
Pearl Harbor, on the Island of O'ahu, Hawaii, (then a territory of the United States) was attacked by the Japanese Imperial Navy, at approximately 8:00 A.M., Sunday morning, December 7, 1941. The surprise attack had been conceived by Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto. The striking force of 353 Japanese aircraft was led by Commander Mitsuo Fuchida. There had been no formal declaration of war.
Approximately 100 ships of the U.S. Navy were present that morning, consisting of battleships, destroyers, cruisers and various support ships.
USS Arizona (BB39) Battleship USS West Virginia (BB48) Battleship USS California (BB44) Battleship USS Oklahoma (BB37) Battleship USS Nevada (BB36) Battleship USS Pennsylvania (BB38) Battleship (in dry dock #1) USS Tennessee (BB43) Battleship USS Maryland (BB46) Battleship USS Vestal (AR4) Repair ship USS Neosho (AO23) Oiler USS Detroit (CL8) Light cruiser USS Raleigh (CL7) Light cruiser USS Utah (AG16) Target Ship USS Tangier (AV8) Seaplane Tender
Two destroyers, the USS Cassin (DD372) and the USS Downes (DD375) were in dry dock #1 (with the USS Pennsylvania) and the destroyer USS Shaw (DD373) was in floating dry dock #2, approximately two hundred yards to the west. The USS Ogala (CM-4) was moored next to the USS Helena (CL50) near the "1010" dock, Naval Ship yard. Two heavy cruisers, the USS New Orleans (CA32) and the San Francisco (CA38) were in the Navy Yard Repair Basin
Over half the U.S. Pacific fleet was out to sea, including the carriers.
Simultaneously, nearby Hickam Field was also the victim of the surprise attack by the Japanese. 18 Army Aircorps aircraft including bombers and fighters and attack bombers were destroyed or damaged on the ground. A few U.S. fighters struggled into the air against the invaders and gave a good account of themselves.
A total of twenty-nine Japanese aircraft were shot down by ground fire and U.S pilots from various military installations on O'ahu.
export.appraisal: To be held permanently in the PastPerfect Museum.
export.associate: More World War II films are available at the World War Two Museum of Pottstown, 1234 S. Union Street, Pottstown, PA. 19342. 610-555-5678.
export.copies: The film is available on videotape or in digital format through this repository.
export.creator: Roosevelt, Franklin D.
export.custodial: This film was acquired by donation and has been in the archives of PastPerfect Museum since 2004.
export.descrip: 16mm film of Franklin Roosevelt asking congress to declare war on Japan, December 8, 1941.
export.extent: Six-minute film of FDR speech to congress December 8, 1941.
export.legal: This film is in the public domain. Copies of the film may be obtained from this repository. A use fee and reproduction costs may be charged.
export.originals: Original film resides in the Smithsonian Institution Film Archives.
export.physchar: To view the entire film requires the use of a 16mm film projector. The 30 second film clip may be viewed through the PastPerfect Software program.
export.related: See accession# 2003.1 for WWII archival materials and photographs.
export.rights: Copies of the film may be obtained from this repository. A use fee and reproduction costs may be charged.
export.subjects: Legislative bodies World War II Presidents & the Congress Naval yards & naval stations
export.system: This item is stored with other films in the climate-controlled film vault of the PastPerfect Museum.
export.title: US Enters World War II

export.creator: Gregory, Ethel
export.descrip: Letter from Ethel Gregory to Neil Packwood, Sr., February 10, 1888. This letter is between the courting couple, who would marry in March 1902.
export.people: Packwood, Ethel Gregory Packwood, Neil Sr.

export.admin: Materials passed from the Chester Paper Box Company owner, Horace Jefferson, directly to his grandson, Humphrey Jefferson.
export.creator: Chester Paper Box Company
export.descrip: Corporate records for Chester Paper Box Company. This company operated from 1875 to 1911. It was a major employer in the Chester County area. Horace Jefferson was the original owner of the company. At his death the collection (15 linear feet of documents, photographs, blueprints, correspondence) were bequeathed to his grandson Humphrey Jefferson.
export.title: Corporate Records, 1875-1911

export.condnotes: Due to condition, this piece should be photographed with a digital camera and not scanned.
export.credit: In memory of my grandfather, Thomas Greene, who loved old photographs.
export.descrip: Account ledger, 1858 -- accounts of business transactions for transporting goods in the Philadelphia area. This ledger has entries starting in the front and back. It appears that the children of the Marshall family practiced handwriting and mathematics in this book as well. There are also a couple of cooking recipes.
export.title: Marshall Account Ledger

export.access: Archives patrons may handle original postcard while wearing cotton gloves.
export.caption: Postcard front
export.condnotes: Edges of the postcard are a bit worn, particularly at the corners.
export.creator: Simmons, Mabel
export.custodial: Postcard is addressed to Ruth Pratt, and mailed from Indianapolis, IN on March 13, 1912. Found in the museum's collection in 2014 with unknown provenance.
export.descrip:
Color postcard of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway sent to Ruth Pratt from her sister, Mabel. The postcard was cancelled on Mar 13 1912, 4:30 PM, Indianapolis, IND. A one cent postage stamp is affixed to the upper right corner of the back side.
Front of postcard is a watercolor-like depiction of the speedway. Several cars are going around the track. The grand stands and boxes are at the far end of the track. There are quite a few small buildings on the infield, across from the grand stands. Surrounding landscape is rural.
Handwritten message says: "The pictures of you at the piana [sic] were very good. Did you have them taken while Mamma was here? Be a good girl. Your sister, Mabel."
export.legal: Postcard was found in the attic. It was located in a box with other archival items that had been cataloged, but no number was found on this item. We were also unable to locate any relevant paperwork for this postcard.
export.notes: Printed text on the postcard back includes: The Speedway has an area of 328 acres. Total cost over $700,000. Circumference of track 2 miles. Grand Stands and Boxes will accommodate 40,000. Entire grounds will accommodate 200,000. Ten thousand automobiles can be parked on the grounds.
export.originals: Originals held in the PastPerfect Museum
export.people: Pratt, Ruth Elizabeth Simmons Simmons, Mabel
export.title: Indianapolis Motor Speedway, The Greatest Race Course in the World

export.access: Archives patrons may handle original postcard while wearing cotton gloves.
export.authorx: Braun Post Card Co, Cleveland, OH
export.caption: Postcard front
export.condnotes: Corners are a bit worn and frayed. The bottom left corner (when viewing from front) has a small crease.
export.custodial: Postcard is addressed to Mr. Peter Petersen, and mailed from Cleveland, OH in Feb 1914. Found in the museum's collection in 2014 with unknown provenance.
export.descrip:
Color postcard of the Motordrome at Luna Park from 1914. The front of the postcard depicts spectators in the infield watching a motorcylce race. Stands on the far side of the track are full of people. Infield is more sparsely populated and includes several cars.
The postcard was mailed to Peter Peterson from his mother and includes a handwritten note on the back side. It was postmarked Feb, 1914 from Cleveland, Ohio, and has a one cent postage stamp affixed to the back.
Handwritten message says: "Cleveland d 8th Feb 1914. Dear Sam, Well, how are you? We are pretty well here exept [sic] a cold some of us have, it is quite cold here now. I suppose it is winter out by you too now, we have just one chicken and our roster now. Something was in the coop and killed all the others Friday night. There is 10 dead laying around in the yard. Pa think it was a dog or fox. Love from all, write soon. Mother."
export.legal: Postcard was found in the attic. It was located in a box with other archival items that had been cataloged, but no number was found on this item. We were also unable to locate any relevant paperwork for this postcard.
export.originals: Original held in the PastPerfect Museum
export.title: Motordrome at Luna Park
